newsitem.title: USA: Intel leads semis down amid tech selloff.
newsitem.headline: Intel leads semis down amid tech selloff.

text.p: In a market jittery over Intel Corp's quarterly earnings announcement due Monday, investors dumped the stock for a third straight session and abandoned most other semiconductor issues, traders said.
In Nasdaq trade, Intel fell 4-1/4, or 3.1 percent to 133 in heavy trade, extending a two-day falloff from 145-1/4.
The negative sentiment was thickened by speculation that Intel will maker deeper-than-usual price cuts in its Pentium chips, the traders added.
Intel said it intends to lower prices by the end of April, but declined to say by how much.
Meanwhile, the Philadeplphia Stock Exchange semiconductor index was off 5.2 points, or 1.8 percent, to 274.5.
Traders said Intel investors are fretting over the pervasiveness of a so-called "whisper number" that raises the expectations for Intel's first quarter income.
The formal expectation is an analysts' consensus view of $2.05 per share, according to Zack's Investment Research, while the whisper number is roughly $0.10 to $0.15 above that, traders said.
Among the semiconductor index, Xilinx Inc was the sole gainer among 16 components with a 3/4 rise to 47-5/8.

In addition to Intel, big losers among the group included Advanced Micro Devices Inc, off 1-1/2 to 38-1/4, VLSI Technology Inc down one to 17-3/4, Teradyne Inc off one to 32, Motorola down 1-1/4 at 58-1/2 and Texas Instruments Inc was 1-3/8 lower at 81-1/4.

An exception among the weaker chip stocks was Dallas Semiconductor Corp, which rallied 5-1/2 to 32, a 20 percent gain, after the company reported first quarter earnings last night well above Wall Street expectations.
The company said it earned $0.50 per share in the period ended March 30, up from $0.36 one year ago and $0.10 better than the Zack's consensus forecast.
Computer networking shares were also heavily sold Friday, in activity that was driven by a series earnings of reports released after last night's market close.
Ascend Communications Inc and Cascade Communications Corp, which agreed to merge last month in a stock-swap deal that was then valued at $3.7 billion, both announced quarterly results.
While Ascend, the buyer of Cascade, reported operating earnings of $0.36 per share, $0.03 above the Wall Street consensus, Cascade disappointed with below-expectation results.
In Nasdaq trade, Cascade shares were off three to 27-3/8 and Ascend declined 3-1/8 to 43-1/4.
Other netorking issues also fell: Cisco Systems dropped 1-1/2 to 51-1/8, DSC Communications shed 1/4 to 20-1/4 and U.S. Robotics lost 3/4 to 54-7/8.
